content: Often times I want to write line (n+1) of a proof while looking at the goal window for line n. I usually just write my new line as a comment, so the current goal state doesn't change. However, I am wondering if there is a better way pause the LSP from updating the goal window. Is this possible? Thanks!

Yeah pausing the updating for the goal buffer is nice. Maybe an alternative way is writing some function to automatically create a "snapshot" buffer for the goal buffer like

(defun xah-new-empty-buffer ()
  "Create a new empty buffer.
Returns the buffer object.
New buffer is named untitled, untitled<2>, etc.

Warning: new buffer is not prompted for save when killed, see `kill-buffer'.
Or manually `save-buffer'

URL `http://xahlee.info/emacs/emacs/emacs_new_empty_buffer.html'
Created: 2017-11-01
Version: 2022-04-05"
  (interactive)
  (let ((xbuf (generate-new-buffer "untitled")))
    (switch-to-buffer xbuf)
    (funcall initial-major-mode)
    xbuf
    ))

? Here the snippet creating an untitled buffer. Some logic for automatically copying the goal buffer to it should be added though

iiuc, this feature request is already formulated in this issue:
https://github.com/leanprover-community/lean4-mode/issues/22

and iiuc, the fork of ultronozom / @Paul Nelson provides this feature. see https://github.com/ultronozm/eldoc-icebox.el and https://github.com/ultronozm/czm-lean4.el and https://github.com/ultronozm/lean4-mode

On a related note, is there a simple way to keep the info buffer updating, but freeze the position at which the goal state is queried and/or which message is scrolled to in the info buffer? I think it could help to edit code earlier in a file and see what effect it has on a proof state at a point or a command's output later in the file. (I vaguely remember that there might have been a feature in the Emacs mode for Lean 3 allowing one of the messages in the info buffer to be pinned to the top, i.e., the second of these features.)
There is a "pin" icon do to this in the VSCode infoview, perhaps you are remembering from it? (if you ever used it, of course)
